attributes.title: Long-term inference and memory and metacognition following retrieval practice
Reference dependence and Investing Risk Tolerance

q1.value: Reference dependence and investment risk tolerance

q3.value: We are interested in how individuals’ tolerance of and preferences for risk depend on contextual reference points. Secondly, we would like to explore if and how risk tolerance is affected by economic scarcity.

q4.value:
h1: we hypothesize that the choice set presented to individuals will significantly shape their investment portfolio selection.

h2: we expect that there will be no differences in risk tolerance between scarcity conditions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants will be asked to imagine that they have the opportunity to invest a sum of money. Then, participants will be presented with a set of 4 different investment portfolios to choose from. They are asked to select which of the portfolios they would choose to invest in if they had the opportunity.

Participants will be randomly shown one of 3 different sets of portfolios, each varying by the distribution of risk across the portfolios. 

Set A: 
Lowest risk portfolio	
Low risk portfolio	
Medium-low risk portfolio	
Medium-high risk portfolio

Set B:
Low risk portfolio	
Medium-low risk portfolio	
Medium-high risk portfolio	
High risk portfolio

Set C:
Medium-low risk portfolio	
Medium-high risk portfolio	
High risk portfolio	
Highest risk portfolio


Participants in the “low risk distribution” condition will be shown set A.
Participants in the “even risk distribution” condition will be shown set B.
Participants in the “high risk distribution” condition will be shown set C.

Each condition will be evaluated based on the distribution of selected portfolios. We hypothesize that responses to Set B (the even risk distribution) will be close to normally distributed. We hypothesize that responses to Sets A and C will be skewed, each with a higher percentage of responses reflecting the reduced variation in risk at either the high end (Set A) or the low end (Set C). If the distribution of responses to Set A and C are not skewed, we can infer that people’s tolerance and preferences for risk are in some part dependent on the options presented.

Participants will also be randomly assigned into a scarcity condition. The scarcity prime will follow the same structure as those used in previous research on scarcity. The low prime involves asking participants to imagine that they have an unexpected car repair of $300 and to answer how difficult it would be for them to handle that expense. The high prime asks the same question but instead of $300, the expense is $3000.

q9.value: Randomization is at the individual level using randomizer within Qualtrics. Condition assignment is randomly determined by meta-data ID.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data is collected through an online survey and sample is drawn from Amazon's mTurk. Survey participants will be compensated commiserate with minimum wage (survey estimated at 5 minutes, $0.60). Only participants who fully complete the survey will be included and no restrictions will be placed regarding demographic characteristics.

Within the survey, there is will be an attention check. All respondents will be paid but responses that fail the attention check will be removed from the analysis.

q14.value: Power analyses conducted in Stata for a test of proportions with a conservative estimate of effect size (5-10 % point change) at .8 level. Sample ranges between 516-676. A larger effect size/smaller sample is more practically meaningful and less costly.

q15.value: Survey will only collect responses to the desired sample size.

question.value:
Choice set
Respondents will be randomly shown 1 of 3 different investment choice sets that differ in distribution of risk between choices.

Scarcity
Respondents will primed at different levels to a scarcity mindset

Proportion of investment risk:
We will use single investment portfolio selections to compare the proportion of respondents who selected between 3 levels of investment risk (conservative, balanced, and growth).

We will use a test of proportions to compare % of selected responses within each category and by scarcity condition

We will also run a logistic model predicting the likelihood of selecting low/high risk portfolios by condition, interacting with scarcity and controlling for an array of demographics.

q20.value:
There are six investment portfolios that have been designed each with increasing risk. The lowest two will be grouped as "conservative", the middle two grouped as "balanced" and the higher two grouped as "growth".

These will be coded as 1-3 in the data set.

q21.value: P values at 0.05 are significant, 0.1 are marginally significant. All tests are two-tailed

q22.value: Within the survey, there is will be an attention check. All respondents will be paid but responses that fail the attention check will be removed from the analysis.

q23.value: All responses that are not 100% complete will be removed from the analysis

q3.value: We are interested in proposing an additional survey exploring how budgeting informs the ways individuals make singular spending decisions. Specifically, we are interested in better understanding how individuals incorporate budget references points into their spending decisions, both within a single time period and across multiple time periods.

q4.value:
h1: there is no significant difference in likelihood to purchase between conditions. If we see significant differences, we will infer that how a spending is positioned within the context of a weekly budget changes the likelihood of making the decision to spend.

h2: Participants who are reminded of their future budgets will view themselves as more likely to reduce spending in the future.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We are proposing a 2x3 experimental design:
Under budget / 
At budget / 
Over budget

by:

Reminder of progress towards future spending goal /			
No reminder of progress towards future spending goal			

Participants will be asked to imagine they are coming home from work. They are presented a choice: either to order take-out from their favorite restaurant or to cook at home. They are then told they have previously given themselves a budget of $30 to spend on food each week and shown a summary of their last 10 expenses.

Participants are then randomly assigned into one of three weekly spending conditions. 
•	In the “under budget” condition, their spending on food this week adds up to $29, or just under their budget.
•	In the “at budget” condition, their spending on food this week adds up to exactly $30, or exactly their budget.
•	In the “over budget” condition, their spending on food this week adds up to $31, or just over their budget.

Participants will also be randomly assigned into one of two future spending conditions.
In the “reminder” condition, participants will be additionally told that even though ordering takeout will put them over their weekly budget, they have only spent half of their budget for the full month. They are also shown a “monthly budget” graphic depicting their spending showing opportunities to reduce future spending.
•	In the “no reminder” condition, participants are not reminded of their monthly budget.

All participants are then asked, on a scale 0%-100%, how likely they are to purchase take-out even though they have groceries at home.

All participants are also asked, on a scale 0%-100%, how likely they are to reduce spending on food in the following week.

q14.value: Power analyses conducted in Stata for a multiple regression model for conservative effect size (0.05-0.03 change in slope) estimates with 3-6 regressors at .8 level. Sample ranges from 266-447.

q15.value: Survey will run only until 450 responses are collected.

question.value:
Contextualized spending:
Each participant is asked to make a decision around buying food. They will be presented with their current spending in relation to a set weekly spending goal: just under, exactly equal, and just over.

Future reminders:
Half of all participants will also be randomly shown how this week's spending is contextualized within the broader month. Although their decision to overspend will exceed this week's spending, it is exactly half of the full month's spending.

Willingness to spend:
All participants are then asked, on a scale 0%-100%, how likely they are to purchase take-out even though they have groceries at home.

Willingness to reduce in the future:
All participants are also asked, on a scale 0%-100%, how likely they are to reduce spending on food in the following week.

We will run 2 multivariate regression models using 1-100 responses as independent variables and categorical condition variable as regressors. We will also include an interaction term between both conditions. We will collect a set of demographic factors as potential control variables.

q1.value: Effects of instructions on performance and motivation for participants high and low in approach and avoidance motivation.

q2.value: Rylie Winsor, Joseph Beaver, Joseph Wayand

q3.value: We are students at Walsh University who are interested in how motivation plays a role in ones performance. In order to test this, we will provide participants with either approach or avoidance motivation instructions and then ask them to complete a 2 minute anagram task containing 3 practice sets and 7 experimental sets. Participants will either be told they have the opportunity to earn 2 tickets if they successfully find 90% or more of the possible words in the anagram (approach motivation), or that they should not miss more than 10% of all the possible words in order to not lose their tickets (avoidance). Finally, in order to measure how much a participant identifies with a certain motivational style, they will be given a BIS/BAS questionnaire that provides a score based on motivation.

q4.value: We hypothesize that those who are given instructions that match their motivational style reported on the BIS/BAS will perform better on the anagram task than those who experience a mismatch. We also hypothesize that overall, those who are approach motivated will perform better than those who are avoidance motivated.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The experiment features 2 separate independent variables: the BIS/BAS and a manipulation of instructions for a task. The dependent variable is the number of correct responses on a simple anagram task. In order to prevent the order of these tasks from influencing the result, they have been counterbalanced. Participants will select research times on the SONA system and will be assigned prior to their arrival into the approach or avoidance motivation instruction conditions. Participants will then report to the Psych Lab at their designated time. Participants will be greeted by one of the two researchers and escorted into one of the classrooms within the lab. Participants will then receive either the approach instructions or avoidance instructions.  For the anagram activity, participants will be given 3 practice anagrams to familiarize themselves with the format before being given 10 real anagrams. Participants sorted into the approach motivation condition will be told that for this set of anagrams the researchers wanted the students to find more than 90% of the possible words. If the participant is successful in finding 90% or more of the words, the student will be rewarded with 2 tickets to a drawing to win a gift card. The experiment will use mild deception, with participants being told that the number of tickets that they will receive will be contingent on their performance during the task. This is not true, as participants will all have an equal chance to win the gift card. Participants sorted into the avoidance motivation condition will be presented with these two tickets prior to the start of their test and told that they will lose the tickets if they missed more than 10% of the possible words. Participants will also complete the BIS/BAS, which consists of 22 questions designed to evaluate a person’s motivational preference. Participants will then be debriefed, and their tickets will be entered into the drawing equally regardless of their scores.

We will follow the Method section that is viewable under our Method component. View our IRB document for details on human subjects treatment / recruitment etc. 

If a participant does not take the experiment seriously and does not give a good-faith effort, they will be dropped from the data set. We define this as solving less than 2 anagrams.

question.value: See our Method.
See our Method

Our design is a 2 X 2 fully between-subjects ANOVA.  The DV is # of anagrams unscrambled. There are two IVs. The first has 2 levels (approach motivation inducing instructions or avoidance motivation inducing instructions) and is randomly assigned. The second IV is a participant characteristic, namely their score on the BIS/BAS instrument. We will create the two levels by scoring the test, finding the median, and thus create a group of approach-oriented and a group of avoidance-oriented.

q25.value: This is a student project for a senior research course at Walsh University. See our IRB for a brief literature review.

attributes.description: We are students at Walsh University who are interested in how motivation plays a role in ones performance. In order to test this, we will provide participants with either approach or avoidance motivation instructions and then ask them to complete a 2 minute anagram task containing 3 practice sets and 7 experimental sets. Participants will either be told they have the opportunity to earn 2 tickets if they successfully find 90% or more of the possible words in the anagram (approach motivation), or that they should not miss more than 10% of all the possible words in order to not lose their tickets (avoidance). Finally, in order to measure how much a participant identifies with a certain motivational style, they will be given a BIS/BAS questionnaire that provides a score based on motivation. We hypothesize that those who are given instructions that match their motivational style reported on the BIS/BAS will perform better on the anagram task than those who experience a mismatch. We also hypothesize that overall, those who are approach motivated will perform better than those who are avoidance motivated.

Finally, in order to measure how much a participant identifies with a certain motivational style, they will be given a BIS/BAS questionnaire that provides a score based on motivation.
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesize that those who are given instructions that match their motivational style reported on the BIS/BAS will perform better on the anagram task than those who experience a mismatch. We also hypothesize that overall, those who are approach motivated will perform better than those who are avoidance motivated.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

registration_responses.q13: We plan to run 80 participants, or as close to 80 before our semester ends.
registration_responses.q14: THis will give us 20 participants per cell.
registration_responses.q15: We will stop at 80.  If we run out of time in the semester, we will stop earlier. We will not look at or analyze the data before stopping.
registration_responses.q25: This is a student project for a senior research course at Walsh University. See our IRB for a brief literature review.
registration_responses.q8.question: The experiment features 2 separate independent variables: the BIS/BAS and a manipulation of instructions for a task. The dependent variable is the number of correct responses on a simple anagram task. In order to prevent the order of these tasks from influencing the result, they have been counterbalanced. Participants will select research times on the SONA system and will be assigned prior to their arrival into the approach or avoidance motivation instruction conditions. Participants will then report to the Psych Lab at their designated time. Participants will be greeted by one of the two researchers and escorted into one of the classrooms within the lab. Participants will then receive either the approach instructions or avoidance instructions.  For the anagram activity, participants will be given 3 practice anagrams to familiarize themselves with the format before being given 10 real anagrams. Participants sorted into the approach motivation condition will be told that for this set of anagrams the researchers wanted the students to find more than 90% of the possible words. If the participant is successful in finding 90% or more of the words, the student will be rewarded with 2 tickets to a drawing to win a gift card. The experiment will use mild deception, with participants being told that the number of tickets that they will receive will be contingent on their performance during the task. This is not true, as participants will all have an equal chance to win the gift card. Participants sorted into the avoidance motivation condition will be presented with these two tickets prior to the start of their test and told that they will lose the tickets if they missed more than 10% of the possible words. Participants will also complete the BIS/BAS, which consists of 22 questions designed to evaluate a person’s motivational preference. Participants will then be debriefed, and their tickets will be entered into the drawing equally regardless of their scores.

We will follow the Method section that is viewable under our Method component. View our IRB document for details on human subjects treatment / recruitment etc. 

If a participant does not take the experiment seriously and does not give a good-faith effort, they will be dropped from the data set. We define this as solving less than 2 anagrams.

registration_responses.q19.question: Our design is a 2 X 2 fully between-subjects ANOVA.  The DV is # of anagrams unscrambled. There are two IVs. The first has 2 levels (approach motivation inducing instructions or avoidance motivation inducing instructions) and is randomly assigned. The second IV is a participant characteristic, namely their score on the BIS/BAS instrument. We will create the two levels by scoring the test, finding the median, and thus create a group of approach-oriented and a group of avoidance-oriented.

q1.value: Sound symbolism in monolingual and bilingual children

q3.value:
Language has long been assumed to be arbitrary (de Saussure, 1959). Ongoing research draws a different picture. There is an increasing number of studies that show nonarbitrary features of language, e.g. sound symbolism. Sound symbolism is the correspondence between the sound and the meaning of a word (Monaghan, Mattock & Walker, 2012). Examples for this phenomenon are: English words beginning with /gl/ are often associated with “vision” and “light” (e.g., “glimmer,” “glisten,” “glitter,” “gleam,” “glow,” “glint”; Aryani, Jacobs & Conrad, 2013), or german words beginning with kno/knö are associated with small, round objects (e.g. “Knöchel”, “Knödel”, “Knopf”; Aryani, Jacobs & Conrad, 2013). These examples are language-specific, but there is evidence that there are some universal sound symbolic associations. Imai, Kita, Naguma & Okada (2008) found that adults can guess antonym translations of possible japanese words. English and Japanese adults made similar judgements what the word could mean. Nygaard, Cook and Nami (2009) used Japanese words to measure sound symbolism. In the learning phase, they presented the participants either correct translations, antonym translations, or unrelated translations of Japanese words. In the test phase, the participants heard the words again and should pick the learned translation. When the participants heard the correct translation, they were faster in picking the learned translation than when they heard the antonym or the unrelated translation. There is another phenomenon, called Bouba-Kiki. In this sound to shape matching task, adult participants map the sound “bouba” to round shapes and the sound “kiki” to angular shapes (Köhler, 1929; Ramachandran & Hubbard, 2001). This preference is found in several cultures (Chen, Huang, Woods, & Spence, 2016), even in cultures not having much contact to western culture nor attending any school system (Bremner et al. 2013). Bremner et al. (2013) researched the Bouba-Kiki phenomenon in Himba people and found that 28 out of 34 participants matched bouba to a round shape and 28 out of 34 participants matched kiki to the angular shape. Not only adults, but as well children as young as 11 months are sensitive to sound-shape correspondences. Laing (2017) presented 10/11 months old children 2 pictures on a screen, one was the matching image to a sound and one was a distractor. She differed the sounds between conventional words (e.g. duck, dog) or onomatopoeic words (e.g. quaak, wouff) and measured on an eye tracker, how long the children looked at the matching image. Laing (2017) compared the time looking to the matching image and the distractor image. She found that the proportion children looked at the matching image when she presented the onomatopoeic word was higher than it was when she presented the conventional word. Another study researching the Bouba-Kiki phenomenon in 11 months old children found an increased N400 response in mismatch conditions – when bouba is matched to angular shapes – than in match conditions – when bouba is matched to round shapes (Asano et al. 2016). This suggests that the association of bouba to angular shapes is more difficult to learn than the association of bouba to round shapes. There are other studies that researched the Bouba-Kiki phenomenon in children. Yoshida (2012) found the bouba-kiki effect in 30 months old children, and Tzeng, Nygaard and Namy (2017) found the effect in 3, 5 and 7-year-old children. Fort et al. (2018) did a meta-analysis on the bouba-kiki phenomenon in children. They found that children are sensitive to sound symbolic matches. In their meta-analysis, the effect was stronger for round shapes than for angular shapes, and the effect was stronger for older children than for younger children. Another study from Perry, Perlman and Lupvan (2015) asked parents to judge, which words their children learn with which age. Then they asked another sample of adults how sound symbolic these words were. Perry et al. (2015) found out that sound symbolic words tend to be learned earlier, leading to the suggestion that sound symbolism helps children to learn language. Imai and Kita (2014) propose the sound symbolic bootstrapping hypothesis. According to it, sound symbolism helps children to learn language. They make 5 claims how sound symbolism helps children to learn language:
The first claim says that children are sensitive to sound symbolism through the ability to map and integrate multi-modal input. This means that children can integrate several aspects of the same word, e.g. the sound and the meaning of the word at the same time. The 2nd claim Imai & Kita (2014) make is that children are sensitive to a wider range of sound symbolic cues than adults, and this sensitivity decreases and gets language specific as children learn more words in their native language. This claim leads to the next one, that sound symbolism helps infants in the early stage of word learning to recognize that speech sounds refer to specific entities in the world. The 4th claim tells that sound symbolism helps infants to associate speech sounds to the specific referent. In doing so, children can establish a lexical representation of this association. The last claim Imai & Kita make is that sound symbolism helps toddlers to identify the specific referent of a word in a complex scene. Could it be that bilingual children don’t lose the broad sensitivity to sound symbolism, as Imai & Kita (2014) propose in their 2nd claim, or that bilingual children lose this broad sensitivity later in life because they know less words compared to monolingual children with the same age?
There are few studies researching sound symbolism in bilingual children. A study of Pejovic and Molnar (2017) compared Spanish/Basque bilingual with Spanish monolingual children in their ability to match bouba to round shapes and kiki to angular shapes. They found no difference in 12 months old children. This makes sense, because neither of these children have more linguistic experience. In the age of 6-8 years, Chow and Ciaramitaro (2019) found in the Bouba-Kiki task, that there is an effect of the number of protrusions with the letter a. When bilingual children were excluded, the effect of 7 protrusions with the letter a was smaller, suggesting that bilingual children are still more sensitive to sound symbolism than monolingual children. Thom and Sandhofer (2013) did a sound label task with 18/24 months old children. They presented the children novel objects. In the training phase, they first placed a novel object in front of the child and it was able to play with the object. After some playing time, the experimenter labeled the object with a pseudo word (e.g. whoosh). After labeling the novel object the experimenter put it away and put a known object in front of the child to play with. After some playing time, the experimenter took the known object away and presented a second novel object the child was able to play with. Then, the experimenter took the object and showed it to the child in a similar way than the first object, but the experimenter didn’t label the object. After, the experimenter put the 2nd novel object away and presented a known object the child could play with. This testing phase was repeated twice. After the 2nd time, the experimenter put 3 novel objects in front of the child to play with. One was the familiar labeled, one the familiar unlabeled and one an unfamiliar novel object. After some playing time the experimenter asked the child to hand over the labeled object (can you give me the whoosh?). Thom & Sandhofer (2013) found out that older bilingual children performed the same as younger children, but monolingual older children performed worse than the other groups.
A possible explanation for this finding is that the sensitivity to sound symbolism decreases with the amount of words children know, as proposed by Imai & Kita (2014). There is some evidence that bilingual children are more sensitive to sound symbolism than monolingual children, but there are few studies researching this. It is as well not clear whether bilingual children lose the broad sensitivity to sound symbolism or whether they lose it later than monolingual children. So, my research question is the following: Are bilingual children more sensitive to sound symbolism than monolingual children are? There are effects for 24 Months old children, but no study compared monolinguals and bilinguals by the age of 36 months. In my study, I research the difference of monolingual and bilingual children in their sensitivity to sound symbolic cues in language. When I find a higher sensitivity of bilingual vs monolingual 36 months old children to sound symbolism, this supports the sound symbolic bootstrapping hypothesis, namely that bilingual children don’t lose the broad sensitivity to sound symbolism as they know less words in one language. When I find the same sensitivity to sound symbolism of bilingual vs. monolingual children to sound symbolism, this would not support the sound symbolic bootstrapping hypothesis, or it would mean that bilingual children caught up with their vocabulary size and don’t use more sound symbolic cues for language learning than monolingual children.

q4.value:
1.	Bilingual 36 months old children can learn sound symbolic words better in a sound label task than monolingual children. Bilingual children should perform better because they know less words in one language (Bialystok, Luk, Peets, & Yang, 2009) and still use sound symbolic cues to learn new words (Perry et al., 2015). With this task I measure children’s ability to learn new sound symbolic words.
2.	Bilingual 36 months old children can match sound symbolic words from Ewe, Japanese, Korean, Siwu and Semai to images better than monolingual children. Bilingual children should perform better because they know less words in one language (Bialystok et al., 2009) and still use sound symbolic cues to learn new words (Perry et al., 2015). With this task I measure the sensitivity of children to detect sound symbolic cues from foreign languages.
3.	Monolingual 36 months old children show greater accuracy in the bouba-kiki phenomenon than monolingual children in the kiki-subtask,and monolingual and bilingual children perform the same in the bouba-subtask. Monolingual children should perform better in the kiki-subtask because of their increased language proficiency and because the sensitivity to this phenomen increases with language proficiency (Fort et al. 2018). Monolingual and bilingual children should perform the same in the bouba-subtask, because the bouba-subtask is easier and is learned earlier (Fort et al. 2018)
4.	Monolingual and bilingual 36 months old children perform the same in all three tasks. This is the case when bilingual children caught up with monolinguals in their vocabulary size (Imai & Kita, 2014).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 16.1.	My study includes 2 groups (monolingual and bilingual children) and it is a between subject design. All children administer the tasks in the same order. Before coming to the lab, the parents are invited by phone calls and e-mails to participate in the study. They receive the questionnaire for onomatopoeic words and exposure to round/spiky objects sent by e-mail to fill out before the appointment in the lab. When they arrive in the lab, I play with the child that it gets to know me and I instruct the parent(s) what is going to happen the next hour. I give the parent(s) the language exposure questionnaire to fill out during the testing of their child. To get the child interested, I tell a story of an alien, which needs to land on earth because its space ship is broken. For the Alien being able to communicate, both the monolingual and bilingual children hear words in Swiss German and need to show the alien the correct object (this is the Bilex in swiss german). Then, I inform the child that the alien landed at the other side of the world. It needs again the help of the child to understand the language spoken there. Then the child does the guess translation task. After this task, I tell the child that the Alien brought some things with it and wants to show them to the child. The Alien labels the objects (sound label task) and asks for one of the shown objects. After finishing this task, I tell the child that the alien gave me a recording of things it needs to repair its ship, but I have no clue what the Alien means. The child needs to help me, which object of the two it needs (bouba-kiki task). After this task, I tell the child that the alien heard the child knows another language and wants to learn this language (Bilex in second language), or I tell the child that the camera did not work, but the alien absolutely wants to learn swiss german (Bilex in swiss german; order other language). After this last task, I tell that the alien was able to repair its ship and flew home, but it let a basket of presents here from which the child can take one home.

q9.value:
1.	Bouba-Kiki: The randomization of the 16 trials was the following: There are no more than two of the same sound type (Bouba vs Kiki) after each other, there is no more than two times the same sex of the speaker of the word after each other, the colors are approximately the same amount (5 green, 5 blue, 6 red) and the same color doesn’t show up twice in a row. There are two different trial orders, one from the front and one from the back.
2.	Sound label task: The randomization is the following: There are two orders, in one the children hear the correct translation for the first and the third object and hear the opposite translation for the second and the fourth object and vice versa.
3.	Guess translation: The randomization is the following: There are no more than two times the same side of the labelled category. The order of the correct and the incorrect category was individually randomized with numbers from 1 to 10.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 7.1.	I will test children by the age of 36 +/- 3 months. They are recruited through phone calls to parents which registered in the local database. For participating, the children will get a small present after the study. I recruit two different groups of children, one monolingual and one bilingual group. Inclusion criteria for the monolingual group are: Exposure to Swiss German and no exposure to any other language. Inclusion criteria for the bilingual group are: Exposure to Swiss German and 1 other language, exposure to each language is at least 25%, input to other languages is no more than 10%. I will collect data from February 2020 until May 2020.

q13.value: 8.1.	The sample size will be 80 children. In each group there will be 40 children, roughly half female and half male.

q14.value: 9.1.	Sample size was fixed to 80 participants because of time and by default for master theses at the Chair of the Department.

q15.value: The data collecting will be stopped after 80 children.

question.value:
1.	Sound label task: First, I present the children a novel object and they have 15 seconds to play with it. Then, I show them the novel object and label it 3 times with a Japanese adjective (e.g. omoi; engl. heavy). After labelling it I take it away and present the children a known object with which they can play for 15 seconds. After that, I put the known object away and show the children another novel object with the opposite characteristic (e.g. heavy vs. light). They can play again with it for 15 seconds and after I take it in my hand and show it to them. I do the exact same thing as with the labelled object, but I don’t label it. I say for example: this is like this, this is cool, … After, I put it away and present the children again a familiar object they can play with for 15 seconds. This is the training phase. After the training phase, I show the children 3 objects. Two of them they are familiar with, and one they are not familiar with. The one they are not familiar with is in the middle of the two extremes (e.g. between heavy and light). After 30 seconds of playing with the objects, I ask the children: can you give me the one that is “omoi”? There are match trials, where the translation of the labeled word is correct, and there are non-match trials, where I label the antonym (e.g. object: soft, label: hard). I do 4 of these trials per child (trial number 1-4), two match and two mismatch trials and with that I measure whether children can learn new sound symbolic foreign words. The coding is as follows: When children give me the labelled object, they receive 2 points, when they give me the unlabeled known object or the unknown object they receive 0 points.
2.	Bouba-Kiki task: Children see each time 2 different figures (De Carolis et al., 2016) in 1 color (this varies between blue, green and red). Then they hear a sound and I ask them to press on the figure they think matches better. I present them 4 different bouba type sounds (bamu, bouba, goga, mabuma) and 4 different kiki-type sounds (kuhtej, kejkee, teetay, tuhkeetee) (sounds from Tzeng, Nygard & Nami, 2017). I present each sound twice, once by a female voice and once by a male voice.  This results in 16 trials per child (trial number 1-16). With this task I measure the ability of children to match pseudowords and shapes. I score this task as follows: For chosing the round shape when children heard a bouba-type sound, they receive 1 point, and for choosing the angular shape when hearing a bouba-type sound they receive 0 points. For choosing the angular shape when presenting a kiki-type sound, children receive 1 point and for choosing the round shape when presenting a kiki-type sounds they receive 0 points.
3.	Guess translation task: I present the children 10 (trial number 1-10) slides, where on each slide are 6 different images. The three images on the left side belong to a category and the three images of the right side belong to a category. On each slide I play a sound from a foreign language suiting to one of the 2 categories and ask the children which category the children think the word suits. The sounds are from the languages Ewe, Japanese, Korean, Siwu and Semai (Dingemanse et al. 2016). I created 34 categories in advance and validated these categories by adults to get the 20 easiest recognizable categories. With the guess translations task, I measure the sensitivity of children to detect sound symbolic cues from other languages. I hypothesize that bilingual children perform better in this task than monolingual children. I code this task as follows: For choosing the correct category, children get 1 point and for choosing the incorrect category children receive 0 points.
4.	Bilex: The Bilex contains 48 trials on 12 different picture cards. Each card shows 6 objects, having 4 targets and 2 distractors. These distractors have an age of acquisition between 3.8 and 6.5 years. Each picture card is shown 4 times, and every time one of the 4 targets is labeled. Every time the same picture card is shown, the 6 objects on it change their position. There are as well 2 different orders of trials, one Swiss German order and 1 other language order, that the children cannot learn the order because they do this task twice in my study. With the Bilex, I control for the vocabulary size in children. For coding the bilex, the child gets 1 point for picking the target object and 0 points for picking any of the other 5 objects.
5.	Questionnaire for onomatopoeia. In this questionnaire, the parents of the children are asked about the amount of onomatopoeic words children use in their language. The questionnaire contains the following questions: How does your child label this animal/object? Then, they see an image of an animal/object and are asked to type in the animal/object name and the respective sound. When they are bilingual, they should fill in both names and both sounds, when they are monolingual they should only type in the Swiss German name and sound. Next to these four text fields there are four additional textfields where the parents can fill in the amount of time their child uses this expression. Taken together, these four textfields need to sum up to 100. With this task, I control for the use of onomatopoeic words in the language of children. I calculate the average of onomatopoeic words the children use in %.
6.	Number of languages children learn, scored as language group 1 or 2 (1 = monolingual, 2 = bilingual)
7.	Parental highest education of father and mother. The otpions are: Primarschule (1 point), Oberstufe (2 points), Matura (3 points), Bachelorabschluss (4 points), Masterabschluss (5 points), Doktorat (6 points).
8.	Exposure to round and pointy objects: The parents are asked to guess the amount of round/spiky objects being in their household in a questionnaire. The questions are the following: How many round objects are there in your household (very few, a few, middle, many, a lot of)? How many spiky objects are there in your household (very few, a few, middle, many, a lot of)? How many spiky compared to round object does your child see at average?
9.	Language exposure questionnaire: When the parents are in the lab, they are asked to fill out a questionnaire. In this questionnaire, they will write down every caregiver of their child, which language this caregiver talks and how much time the caregiver spends with the child during the week. Out of this questionnaire I calculate, how much time the child is exposed to which language.

1.	I sum up all correct trials in the Bilex. The final scoring will be (Score_Bilex_1 + Score_Bilex_2)/2 for both monolinguals and bilinguals. This is done so to control for fatigue.
2.	I calculate an amount of language exposure for each child, how much Swiss German/other language they hear, which results in time of language exposure to Swiss German/other language. 
3.	I calculate an average for the amount children still use onomatopoeic and conventional words in each language (questionnaire of onomatopoeia). 
4.	I calculate a mean between the mother’s and father’s highest education. 
5.	I calculate the amount of round/spiky objects being in the house.

Hypothesis 1 (Sound label task): I will perform a logistic regression analysis: glmer(Score sound label  ~ language group * trial number + bilex score + parental education + onomatopoeic words + language exposure + (1|subject), family = ordinal)
Hypothesis 2 (Bouba-kiki Task): I will perform a logistic regression analysis: glmer(Score Bouba-Kiki ~ language group * trial number + bilex score + exposure round/spiky + parental education + onomatopoeic words + language exposure + (1|subject), family = binomial)
Hypothesis 3 (Guess-translation task): I will perform a logistic regression analysis: glmer(Score guess translations ~ language group * trial type + bilex + parental education + onomatopoeic words + language exposure + (1|subject), family = binomial)

q21.value: The inference criteria will be a p-value below 0.05.

q22.value: I will exclude children from the bilingual group when their language exposure is less than 25% in one language. I will exclude children from the monolingual group when their language exposure is more than 10% in another language than Swiss German. Children will be excluded when somebody in the room (parent, sibling) interferes, or when the experimenter makes an error, or when there are technical difficulties.

q23.value: Children with missing data will be excluded trial wise. When there is no data for a whole task, the child will be excluded from the analysis in this task.

Could it be that bilingual children don’t lose the broad sensitivity to sound symbolism, as Imai & Kita (2014) propose in their 2nd claim, or that bilingual children lose this broad sensitivity later in life because they know less words compared to monolingual children with the same age?
There are few studies researching sound symbolism in bilingual children. A study of Pejovic and Molnar (2017) compared Spanish/Basque bilingual with Spanish monolingual children in their ability to match bouba to round shapes and kiki to angular shapes. They found no difference in 12 months old children. This makes sense, because neither of these children have more linguistic experience. In the age of 6-8 years, Chow and Ciaramitaro (2019) found in the Bouba-Kiki task, that there is an effect of the number of protrusions with the letter a. When bilingual children were excluded, the effect of 7 protrusions with the letter a was smaller, suggesting that bilingual children are still more sensitive to sound symbolism than monolingual children. Thom and Sandhofer (2013) did a sound label task with 18/24 months old children. They presented the children novel objects. In the training phase, they first placed a novel object in front of the child and it was able to play with the object. After some playing time, the experimenter labeled the object with a pseudo word (e.g. whoosh). After labeling the novel object the experimenter put it away and put a known object in front of the child to play with. After some playing time, the experimenter took the known object away and presented a second novel object the child was able to play with. Then, the experimenter took the object and showed it to the child in a similar way than the first object, but the experimenter didn’t label the object. After, the experimenter put the 2nd novel object away and presented a known object the child could play with. This testing phase was repeated twice. After the 2nd time, the experimenter put 3 novel objects in front of the child to play with. One was the familiar labeled, one the familiar unlabeled and one an unfamiliar novel object. After some playing time the experimenter asked the child to hand over the labeled object (can you give me the whoosh?). Thom & Sandhofer (2013) found out that older bilingual children performed the same as younger children, but monolingual older children performed worse than the other groups.
A possible explanation for this finding is that the sensitivity to sound symbolism decreases with the amount of words children know, as proposed by Imai & Kita (2014). There is some evidence that bilingual children are more sensitive to sound symbolism than monolingual children, but there are few studies researching this. It is as well not clear whether bilingual children lose the broad sensitivity to sound symbolism or whether they lose it later than monolingual children. So, my research question is the following: Are bilingual children more sensitive to sound symbolism than monolingual children are? There are effects for 24 Months old children, but no study compared monolinguals and bilinguals by the age of 36 months. In my study, I research the difference of monolingual and bilingual children in their sensitivity to sound symbolic cues in language. When I find a higher sensitivity of bilingual vs monolingual 36 months old children to sound symbolism, this supports the sound symbolic bootstrapping hypothesis, namely that bilingual children don’t lose the broad sensitivity to sound symbolism as they know less words in one language. When I find the same sensitivity to sound symbolism of bilingual vs. monolingual children to sound symbolism, this would not support the sound symbolic bootstrapping hypothesis, or it would mean that bilingual children caught up with their vocabulary size and don’t use more sound symbolic cues for language learning than monolingual children.
registration_responses.q4:
1.	Bilingual 36 months old children can learn sound symbolic words better in a sound label task than monolingual children. Bilingual children should perform better because they know less words in one language (Bialystok, Luk, Peets, & Yang, 2009) and still use sound symbolic cues to learn new words (Perry et al., 2015). With this task I measure children’s ability to learn new sound symbolic words.
2.	Bilingual 36 months old children can match sound symbolic words from Ewe, Japanese, Korean, Siwu and Semai to images better than monolingual children. Bilingual children should perform better because they know less words in one language (Bialystok et al., 2009) and still use sound symbolic cues to learn new words (Perry et al., 2015). With this task I measure the sensitivity of children to detect sound symbolic cues from foreign languages.
3.	Monolingual 36 months old children show greater accuracy in the bouba-kiki phenomenon than monolingual children in the kiki-subtask,and monolingual and bilingual children perform the same in the bouba-subtask. Monolingual children should perform better in the kiki-subtask because of their increased language proficiency and because the sensitivity to this phenomen increases with language proficiency (Fort et al. 2018). Monolingual and bilingual children should perform the same in the bouba-subtask, because the bouba-subtask is easier and is learned earlier (Fort et al. 2018)
4.	Monolingual and bilingual 36 months old children perform the same in all three tasks. This is the case when bilingual children caught up with monolinguals in their vocabulary size (Imai & Kita, 2014).
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9:
1.	Bouba-Kiki: The randomization of the 16 trials was the following: There are no more than two of the same sound type (Bouba vs Kiki) after each other, there is no more than two times the same sex of the speaker of the word after each other, the colors are approximately the same amount (5 green, 5 blue, 6 red) and the same color doesn’t show up twice in a row. There are two different trial orders, one from the front and one from the back.
2.	Sound label task: The randomization is the following: There are two orders, in one the children hear the correct translation for the first and the third object and hear the opposite translation for the second and the fourth object and vice versa.
3.	Guess translation: The randomization is the following: There are no more than two times the same side of the labelled category. The order of the correct and the incorrect category was individually randomized with numbers from 1 to 10.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: 8.1.	The sample size will be 80 children. In each group there will be 40 children, roughly half female and half male.
registration_responses.q14: 9.1.	Sample size was fixed to 80 participants because of time and by default for master theses at the Chair of the Department.
registration_responses.q15: The data collecting will be stopped after 80 children.
registration_responses.q21: The inference criteria will be a p-value below 0.05.
registration_responses.q22: I will exclude children from the bilingual group when their language exposure is less than 25% in one language. I will exclude children from the monolingual group when their language exposure is more than 10% in another language than Swiss German. Children will be excluded when somebody in the room (parent, sibling) interferes, or when the experimenter makes an error, or when there are technical difficulties.
registration_responses.q23: Children with missing data will be excluded trial wise. When there is no data for a whole task, the child will be excluded from the analysis in this task.
registration_responses.q8.question: 16.1.	My study includes 2 groups (monolingual and bilingual children) and it is a between subject design. All children administer the tasks in the same order. Before coming to the lab, the parents are invited by phone calls and e-mails to participate in the study. They receive the questionnaire for onomatopoeic words and exposure to round/spiky objects sent by e-mail to fill out before the appointment in the lab. When they arrive in the lab, I play with the child that it gets to know me and I instruct the parent(s) what is going to happen the next hour. I give the parent(s) the language exposure questionnaire to fill out during the testing of their child. To get the child interested, I tell a story of an alien, which needs to land on earth because its space ship is broken. For the Alien being able to communicate, both the monolingual and bilingual children hear words in Swiss German and need to show the alien the correct object (this is the Bilex in swiss german). Then, I inform the child that the alien landed at the other side of the world. It needs again the help of the child to understand the language spoken there. Then the child does the guess translation task. After this task, I tell the child that the Alien brought some things with it and wants to show them to the child. The Alien labels the objects (sound label task) and asks for one of the shown objects. After finishing this task, I tell the child that the alien gave me a recording of things it needs to repair its ship, but I have no clue what the Alien means. The child needs to help me, which object of the two it needs (bouba-kiki task). After this task, I tell the child that the alien heard the child knows another language and wants to learn this language (Bilex in second language), or I tell the child that the camera did not work, but the alien absolutely wants to learn swiss german (Bilex in swiss german; order other language). After this last task, I tell that the alien was able to repair its ship and flew home, but it let a basket of presents here from which the child can take one home.
registration_responses.q12.question: 7.1.	I will test children by the age of 36 +/- 3 months. They are recruited through phone calls to parents which registered in the local database. For participating, the children will get a small present after the study. I recruit two different groups of children, one monolingual and one bilingual group. Inclusion criteria for the monolingual group are: Exposure to Swiss German and no exposure to any other language. Inclusion criteria for the bilingual group are: Exposure to Swiss German and 1 other language, exposure to each language is at least 25%, input to other languages is no more than 10%. I will collect data from February 2020 until May 2020.
registration_responses.q17.question:
1.	Sound label task: First, I present the children a novel object and they have 15 seconds to play with it. Then, I show them the novel object and label it 3 times with a Japanese adjective (e.g. omoi; engl. heavy). After labelling it I take it away and present the children a known object with which they can play for 15 seconds. After that, I put the known object away and show the children another novel object with the opposite characteristic (e.g. heavy vs. light). They can play again with it for 15 seconds and after I take it in my hand and show it to them. I do the exact same thing as with the labelled object, but I don’t label it. I say for example: this is like this, this is cool, … After, I put it away and present the children again a familiar object they can play with for 15 seconds. This is the training phase. After the training phase, I show the children 3 objects. Two of them they are familiar with, and one they are not familiar with. The one they are not familiar with is in the middle of the two extremes (e.g. between heavy and light). After 30 seconds of playing with the objects, I ask the children: can you give me the one that is “omoi”? There are match trials, where the translation of the labeled word is correct, and there are non-match trials, where I label the antonym (e.g. object: soft, label: hard). I do 4 of these trials per child (trial number 1-4), two match and two mismatch trials and with that I measure whether children can learn new sound symbolic foreign words. The coding is as follows: When children give me the labelled object, they receive 2 points, when they give me the unlabeled known object or the unknown object they receive 0 points.
2.	Bouba-Kiki task: Children see each time 2 different figures (De Carolis et al., 2016) in 1 color (this varies between blue, green and red). Then they hear a sound and I ask them to press on the figure they think matches better. I present them 4 different bouba type sounds (bamu, bouba, goga, mabuma) and 4 different kiki-type sounds (kuhtej, kejkee, teetay, tuhkeetee) (sounds from Tzeng, Nygard & Nami, 2017). I present each sound twice, once by a female voice and once by a male voice.  This results in 16 trials per child (trial number 1-16). With this task I measure the ability of children to match pseudowords and shapes. I score this task as follows: For chosing the round shape when children heard a bouba-type sound, they receive 1 point, and for choosing the angular shape when hearing a bouba-type sound they receive 0 points. For choosing the angular shape when presenting a kiki-type sound, children receive 1 point and for choosing the round shape when presenting a kiki-type sounds they receive 0 points.
3.	Guess translation task: I present the children 10 (trial number 1-10) slides, where on each slide are 6 different images. The three images on the left side belong to a category and the three images of the right side belong to a category. On each slide I play a sound from a foreign language suiting to one of the 2 categories and ask the children which category the children think the word suits. The sounds are from the languages Ewe, Japanese, Korean, Siwu and Semai (Dingemanse et al. 2016). I created 34 categories in advance and validated these categories by adults to get the 20 easiest recognizable categories. With the guess translations task, I measure the sensitivity of children to detect sound symbolic cues from other languages. I hypothesize that bilingual children perform better in this task than monolingual children. I code this task as follows: For choosing the correct category, children get 1 point and for choosing the incorrect category children receive 0 points.
4.	Bilex: The Bilex contains 48 trials on 12 different picture cards. Each card shows 6 objects, having 4 targets and 2 distractors. These distractors have an age of acquisition between 3.8 and 6.5 years. Each picture card is shown 4 times, and every time one of the 4 targets is labeled. Every time the same picture card is shown, the 6 objects on it change their position. There are as well 2 different orders of trials, one Swiss German order and 1 other language order, that the children cannot learn the order because they do this task twice in my study. With the Bilex, I control for the vocabulary size in children. For coding the bilex, the child gets 1 point for picking the target object and 0 points for picking any of the other 5 objects.
5.	Questionnaire for onomatopoeia. In this questionnaire, the parents of the children are asked about the amount of onomatopoeic words children use in their language. The questionnaire contains the following questions: How does your child label this animal/object? Then, they see an image of an animal/object and are asked to type in the animal/object name and the respective sound. When they are bilingual, they should fill in both names and both sounds, when they are monolingual they should only type in the Swiss German name and sound. Next to these four text fields there are four additional textfields where the parents can fill in the amount of time their child uses this expression. Taken together, these four textfields need to sum up to 100. With this task, I control for the use of onomatopoeic words in the language of children. I calculate the average of onomatopoeic words the children use in %.
6.	Number of languages children learn, scored as language group 1 or 2 (1 = monolingual, 2 = bilingual)
7.	Parental highest education of father and mother. The otpions are: Primarschule (1 point), Oberstufe (2 points), Matura (3 points), Bachelorabschluss (4 points), Masterabschluss (5 points), Doktorat (6 points).
8.	Exposure to round and pointy objects: The parents are asked to guess the amount of round/spiky objects being in their household in a questionnaire. The questions are the following: How many round objects are there in your household (very few, a few, middle, many, a lot of)? How many spiky objects are there in your household (very few, a few, middle, many, a lot of)? How many spiky compared to round object does your child see at average?
9.	Language exposure questionnaire: When the parents are in the lab, they are asked to fill out a questionnaire. In this questionnaire, they will write down every caregiver of their child, which language this caregiver talks and how much time the caregiver spends with the child during the week. Out of this questionnaire I calculate, how much time the child is exposed to which language.
registration_responses.q18.question:
1.	I sum up all correct trials in the Bilex. The final scoring will be (Score_Bilex_1 + Score_Bilex_2)/2 for both monolinguals and bilinguals. This is done so to control for fatigue.
2.	I calculate an amount of language exposure for each child, how much Swiss German/other language they hear, which results in time of language exposure to Swiss German/other language. 
3.	I calculate an average for the amount children still use onomatopoeic and conventional words in each language (questionnaire of onomatopoeia). 
4.	I calculate a mean between the mother’s and father’s highest education. 
5.	I calculate the amount of round/spiky objects being in the house.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Hypothesis 1 (Sound label task): I will perform a logistic regression analysis: glmer(Score sound label  ~ language group * trial number + bilex score + parental education + onomatopoeic words + language exposure + (1|subject), family = ordinal)
Hypothesis 2 (Bouba-kiki Task): I will perform a logistic regression analysis: glmer(Score Bouba-Kiki ~ language group * trial number + bilex score + exposure round/spiky + parental education + onomatopoeic words + language exposure + (1|subject), family = binomial)
Hypothesis 3 (Guess-translation task): I will perform a logistic regression analysis: glmer(Score guess translations ~ language group * trial type + bilex + parental education + onomatopoeic words + language exposure + (1|subject), family = binomial)

attributes.title: Experience and confidence
attributes.description:
This is an experimental study to explore how different forms of presenting information (described or experienced information) to decision makers affect their confidence in choice and confidence in the realiability/trustworthiness of the information.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Decision makers use estimates of the reliability of the information they encounter to make a decision under uncertainty (Aitchison et al. 2015). For example, a manager will wait until the information she consults is deemed sufficiently reliable and trustworthy to make an important strategic decision. These perceptions of the reliability of the information they use can be communicated to third parties to reflect confidence in their beliefs or opinions, which can be useful in group discussions or leadership roles. 
The information used by decision makers to make a choice can typically be accessed in two broad ways: either it is access through their own experience (a sample of previously encountered choices) or through convenient descriptions of the probabilities and outcomes of the choice problem.
In this study, we ask whether the source of information (experience or convenient descriptions) affects decision makers’ confidence level. More precisely, we ask whether the source of information affects two aspects of confidence: (1) confidence in the reliability of the information they used to make the choice, and (2) confidence in having made the right choice. 
Previous studies have emphasized the idea that experience breeds confidence even in settings where skills or expertise do not increase with experience (superstitious learning account). Yet, these changes in confidence have not been compared to other ways of learning about a task (e.g. descriptions of risky choices). We wonder whether some of the differences in choice behavior observed in the ‘DE gap’ literature may relate to differences in confidence brought about by the source of information.

q1.value: Experience and confidence - The role of sample size

q3.value:
This is a follow-up study to explore the relationship between sample size in decisions from experience and confidence. While in two previous studies we found a slightly negative correlation between sample size and confidence in information and in choice, we are unsure whether sample size affected confidence ratings or whether initial confidence drove sample size (e.g. subjects with initially low confidence sampled more than subjects with initiall high confidence).
In this study, we manipulate sample size by fixing it prior to a choice task. In a within-subjects design, participants have to make 40 choices between two monetary gambles. Prior to making each choice, participants have to sample either 5 times each option (small sample condition) or 40 times each option (large sample condition). Every 4th choice, participants are asked to rate their confidence in the information sampled and in the choice made.

q4.value:
For confidence in information, we expect that the larger the sample the higher the confidence rating.

For confidence in choice, the expectation is less clear. Two competing hypotheses are posed.

-The larger the sample, the higher the confidence rating (due to increased confidence in information).

-The smaller the sample, the higher the confidence rating (due to the amplified difference between options which facilitate choice)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants sitting in front of acomputer see two buttons on the screen, each associated with a monetary gamble. They receive no descriptive information about potential outcomes or associated probabilities. Instead, participants can sample each gamble by clicking a button and immediately obtaining information about the payoff corresponding to the chosen gamble. Participants are told that they have to sample a fixed number of times before proceeding to make an incentivized choice between them. In 20 of the choices, they hava to sample 5 times each option (Small sample condition), in the other 20 choices they have to sample 40 times each option (large sample condition). Chioces based on different sample sizes are randomly intermixed. At the outset, all participants will be reminded that their objective is to maximize the amount of money obtained across all 40 choices.

After every fourth choice, participants in both conditions are prompted to report their confidence in information and in their choice:
(1) “Please rate how reliable you think this information is to inform your choice (or how confident are you that the sampled information helped you in choosing the best option)? Move the bar in the rating scale from ‘0’ (not reliable at all) to ‘100’ extremely reliable.” 
(2) “Please rate how confident you are that your choice was correct. Move the bar in the rating scale from ‘0%’ (not confident at all) to ‘100%’ (completely confident).”

The first rating captures participants’ confidence in the information they receive as an input for their choice. The second captures participants’ confidence in their choice. In neither the description condition nor the experience condition participants receive feedback about the choices they made.

Participants are paid 6 euros as a show-up fee and the final compensation amounts to the 6 euros plus the outcome of a randomly selected loterry they choose throughout the experiment. Participants are made aware that some lotteries can have negative payoffs and thus the final compensation can be lower than 6 euros.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit 70 undergraduate students from a Spanish public university. Participants are payed 6 euros as showup feed and the final compensation amounts to the 6 euros plus the payoff obtained from a randombly selected lottery they chose througout the experiment. The expected amount of time for the experiment is 30 minutes per subject.

q13.value: We aim for a sample of 70 subjects to compare with a previous experiment (unpublished) of the same sample size. Each participant will do 40 choices and will be asked about confidence (dependent variables) every 4th choice (10 times). The analysis will be conducted based on the 700 confidence ratinng obtained.

question.value: We manipulate the sample of information that participants can sample: 5 times per option (small sample) and 40 times per option (large sample)

Confidence in information: rating between 0 (not confident at all) and 10 (completely confident)
Confidence in choice: rating between 0 (not confident at all) and 10 (completely confident)

Linear mixed models with random intercepts and slopes. The dependent variables are confidence in information and confidence in choice. The independent variable is sample size. Models are estimated by maximum likelihood and p-values for the estimated coefficients are obtained by likelihood ratio tests of the full model with the effect in question against the model without that effect
