attributes.title: The psychology of sugary drinks - Project 3 - The impact of labels

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Secondary analyses:

We will explore
-	whether sensory and action simulations are affected by label type
o	t.test(sensory.simulations ~ label.type.sim.con, data = data) 
o	t.test(sensory.simulations ~ label.type.sim.brand, data = data) 
-	whether the simulation enhanced labels increase desire, anticipated reward, and sensory and action simulation for sugary drinks compared to control and brand-only labels (exactly the same script as for Hypothesis 1 and Hypothesis 2, but this time, the dependent variable is orange soda)
-	whether healthiness rating of drinks is related to desire, anticipated reward, and sensory and action simulations (with the cor.test function)
-	whether intentions to change behaviour of drinks is related to desire, anticipated reward, and sensory and action simulations (with the cor.test function) of water
-	whether healthiness ratings or intentions to change behaviour moderate the effect of label type on desire for water 
o	aov(desire ~ label.type.sim.con*healthiness/intentions, data = data)
o	aov(desire ~ label.type.sim.brand*healthiness/intentions, data = data)
-	the correlations between frequency and desire, anticipated reward, and sensory and action simulations per drink, with the cor.test function
-	We will conduct robustness checks whether any potential effects in H1-3 hold if we control for thirst:
o	lm(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.con*thirst, data = data) 
o	lm(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.brand*thirst, data = data) 
o	lm(desire ~ label.type.sim.con*thirst, data = data) 
o	lm(desire ~ label.type.sim.brand*thirst, data = data) 
o	# direct effect
desire ~ c*label.type.sim.con + thirst
# mediator
	anticipated.reward ~ a* label.type.sim.con + thirst
	desire ~ b*anticipated.reward + thirst
	# indirect effect
	ab := a*b
	# total effect
	Total := c + (a*b)
-	We will conduct robustness checks whether any potential effects in H1-3 hold if we control for frequency of consuming bottled water:
o	lm(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.con* frequency, data = data) 
o	lm(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.brand* frequency, data = data) 
o	lm(desire ~ label.type.sim.con*frequency, data = data) 
o	lm(desire ~ label.type.sim.brand* frequency, data = data) 
o	# direct effect
desire ~ c*label.type.sim.con + frequency
# mediator
	anticipated.reward ~ a* label.type.sim.con + frequency
	desire ~ b*anticipated.reward + frequency
	# indirect effect
	ab := a*b
	# total effect
	Total := c + (a*b)

sample.value:
For H1 and H2, we calculated sample size with the pwr package in R. This test showed that to detect a d = .4, with 90% power, we need 132 participants per group, so 396 participants in total.

For H3, we simulated data to calculate power in R. As we will run this analysis 2X, we adjusted the p value from p < .05 to p < .025. Based on this data simulation, we need 300 (150 per condition) participants to detect small to medium effect size for the indirect path with 87% power.

Based on these calculations, the total sample size should be N = 450 (150 per group). To account for possible exclusions, we will collect data from 500 participants. 
Participant will be paid 1£ for this study.

analyses.value:
All analysis will be conducted in R:

Note: throughout the script:
label.type.sim.con refers to comparing simulation enhanced vs control conditions
label.type.sim.brand refers to comparing simulation enhanced vs brand only conditions

Hypothesis 1: 
hypothesis.1.a = t.test(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.con, data = data)
hypothesis.1.b = t.test(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.brand, data = data)

Hypothesis 2: 
hypothesis.2.a = t.test(desire ~ label.type.sim.con, data = data)
hypothesis.2.b = t.test(desire ~ label.type.sim.brand, data = data)

Hypothesis 3 (mediation analysis with the lavaan package in R)
hypothesis.3 = 
	‘
	# direct effect
	desire ~ c*label.type.sim.con
	
	# mediator
	anticipated.reward ~ a* label.type.sim.con
	desire ~ b*anticipated.reward
	
	# indirect effect
	ab := a*b
	
	# total effect
	Total := c + (a*b)
	‘
fit = sem(hypothesis.3, data = data)
summary(fit)

We will conduct H3 again (exactly the same script as above), but with label.type.sim.brand as predictor

outliers.value:
A priori inclusion criteria:
We will recruit participants who:
•	are aged between 18-70
•	do not have diabetes, 
•	do not have allergies/medical reasons not to consume any of the drink products, 
•	and are not currently on a weight-loss or other restrictive diet
•	like and consume sugary, fizzy drinks at least once a week

Exclusions:
•	We will instruct participants to fill out the survey on a computer or laptop. Those who do not follow the instructions will be excluded.
•	implausibly short completion time (i.e., 1/3 of the average completion time)

dependent.value:
Measures according to appearance in the survey procedure:
1.	Current thirst (1-100 VAS)
2.	Anticipated reward: participants will be presented with a description of a drink product (between subjects: simulation enhanced, control, brand-only), within subjects: drink type: water, orange soda) and their task will be to rate each drink based on the following statements:
When I read the description of this drink, 
a.	…I imagine that it would be refreshing (bodily)
b.	…I imagine that it would taste very nice (hedonic)
c.	…I imagine that I would really enjoy drinking it (hedonic)
	Participants respond on a 0 – 100 VAS with anchors 0 = not at all, 100 = definitely. 	The final score for “anticipated reward” will be calculated as the average of the three statements.
3.	Sensory and action simulations: participants will be presented with a description of a drink product (between subjects: simulation enhanced, control, brand-only), within subjects: drink type: water, orange soda) and their task will be to rate each drink based on the following statements:
When I read the description of this drink,
a.	…I imagine drinking it (action)
b.	…I imagine what it would taste like (taste)
c.	…I Imagine what it would feel like in my mouth (texture)
Participants respond on a 0 – 100 VAS with anchors 0 = not at all, 100 = definitely. The final score on this item will be calculated as the average of the three statements.
4.	Desire: participants will be presented with a description of a drink product (between subjects: simulation enhanced, control, brand-only), within subjects: drink type: water, orange soda) and their task will be to indicate how much they would like to consume those drinks in the moment (1-100 VAS; anchors: not at all – very much ).
5.	Consumption frequency: we measure frequency of consuming orange soda (any type, Fanta, unbranded etc) and bottled water (any type) on a 0-100 VAS.
6.	Healthiness ratings: we measure how healthy participants think bottled water and orange soda are on a 0-100 VAS.
7.	Intentions to change behaviour: we measure participants’ intentions to change their behaviour with regards to (1) increasing their water consumption, (2) decrease sugary drink consumption, and (3) drinking more water than sugary drinks. They will indicate their responses on a 0-100 VAS. 
8.	Demographics, such as age, gender, BMI

conditions.value:
Our between subject factor is label type with three levels (simulation enhanced, control, and brand-only) and our within-subjects factor is drink type (counterbalanced: water, orange soda). 

In each condition, participants will be presented with two hypothetical drinks: a bottled water named “San Perrio” and an orange soda names “Orange Pop”. The descriptions of these products will differ in each condition:

Simulation enhanced: 
o	“San Perrio, cold and refreshing. An invigorating mineral water that gives your body a new feel, wherever you are.”
o	“Orange Pop, sweet and happy. A fruity, energizing orange soda to share come rain or shine.”

Control
o	“San Perrio, a mineral water. Carefully drawn from Alpine springs on organic protected land.”
o	“Orange Pop, an orange soda. Carefully crafted in the Mediterranean from sun-ripened organic oranges.”

Brand-only
o	“San Perrio, a mineral water.”
o	“Orange Pop, an orange soda.”

Our main interest is water, but we added orange soda for exploratory purposes.

hypothesis.value:
In this experiment, we investigate whether using specific words in advertising can increase the attractiveness of water. In previous studies, we found that when people spontaneously simulate rewarding experiences of drinking water (e.g., it’s cold, refreshing), they more likely desire it. Based on this finding, we test whether using words related to rewarding consumption simulations in advertising increases desire and anticipated reward of water, compared to advertising that mentions only the brand name, or conventional advertising that emphasises the purity and origins of the water. 

Key Hypotheses:

H1: Simulation enhanced labels will increase anticipated reward for water compared to control and brand only labels.

H2: Simulation enhanced labels will increase desire for water compared to control and brand only labels.

H3: Simulation enhanced labels will increase desire for water compared to the control condition through increased anticipated reward (mediation).

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: The impact of labels - Experiment 1
registration_responses.other:
Secondary analyses:

We will explore
-	whether sensory and action simulations are affected by label type
o	t.test(sensory.simulations ~ label.type.sim.con, data = data) 
o	t.test(sensory.simulations ~ label.type.sim.brand, data = data) 
-	whether the simulation enhanced labels increase desire, anticipated reward, and sensory and action simulation for sugary drinks compared to control and brand-only labels (exactly the same script as for Hypothesis 1 and Hypothesis 2, but this time, the dependent variable is orange soda)
-	whether healthiness rating of drinks is related to desire, anticipated reward, and sensory and action simulations (with the cor.test function)
-	whether intentions to change behaviour of drinks is related to desire, anticipated reward, and sensory and action simulations (with the cor.test function) of water
-	whether healthiness ratings or intentions to change behaviour moderate the effect of label type on desire for water 
o	aov(desire ~ label.type.sim.con*healthiness/intentions, data = data)
o	aov(desire ~ label.type.sim.brand*healthiness/intentions, data = data)
-	the correlations between frequency and desire, anticipated reward, and sensory and action simulations per drink, with the cor.test function
-	We will conduct robustness checks whether any potential effects in H1-3 hold if we control for thirst:
o	lm(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.con*thirst, data = data) 
o	lm(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.brand*thirst, data = data) 
o	lm(desire ~ label.type.sim.con*thirst, data = data) 
o	lm(desire ~ label.type.sim.brand*thirst, data = data) 
o	# direct effect
desire ~ c*label.type.sim.con + thirst
# mediator
	anticipated.reward ~ a* label.type.sim.con + thirst
	desire ~ b*anticipated.reward + thirst
	# indirect effect
	ab := a*b
	# total effect
	Total := c + (a*b)
-	We will conduct robustness checks whether any potential effects in H1-3 hold if we control for frequency of consuming bottled water:
o	lm(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.con* frequency, data = data) 
o	lm(anticipated.reward ~ label.type.sim.brand* frequency, data = data) 
o	lm(desire ~ label.type.sim.con*frequency, data = data) 
o	lm(desire ~ label.type.sim.brand* frequency, data = data) 
o	# direct effect
desire ~ c*label.type.sim.con + frequency
# mediator
	anticipated.reward ~ a* label.type.sim.con + frequency
	desire ~ b*anticipated.reward + frequency
	# indirect effect
	ab := a*b
	# total effect
	Total := c + (a*b)
